path_1.title: Devil's Rejects, The (2005)
path_1.feeling: Gritty and mean-spirited road horror that’s effective but not my preferred flavor.

path_1.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
path_1.feeling: Transcendent, hypnotic sci‑fi that hits every awe button for me.

path_1.title: Vampire Hunter D (1985)
path_1.feeling: Moody and stylish but thinly plotted

path_1.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_1.feeling: Darkly whimsical and creepy enough to still charm me.

path_1.title: Housebound (2014)
path_1.feeling: Clever, funny, and tense in the right spots—pleasantly surprised.

path_1.title: FearDotCom (a.k.a. Fear.com) (a.k.a. Fear Dot Com) (2002)
path_1.feeling: Ugly and incoherent

path_1.title: American Haunting, An (2005)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric period chills but repetitive and ultimately tepid.

path_1.title: Queen of the Damned (2002)
path_1.feeling: Glossy but hollow

path_1.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_1.feeling: Derivative cabin-in-the-woods alien flick with a few fun jolts.

path_1.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_1.feeling: Grim, twisty, and riveting even if it leaves me a bit cold emotionally.

path_1.title: Signal, The (2014)
path_1.feeling: Intriguing mystery with stylish sci‑fi turns that don’t fully cohere but kept me hooked.

path_1.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_1.feeling: Taut, claustrophobic suspense with strong performances and a mostly satisfying payoff.

path_1.title: Altered (2006)
path_1.feeling: Grimy, small‑scale alien revenge piece that delivers decent tension.

path_1.title: Pumpkinhead (1988)
path_1.feeling: Creature feature with strong atmosphere and morality tale bones

path_1.title: Innkeepers, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: Slow-burn spookiness with likable leads and a nicely lingering chill.

path_1.title: Bride of Chucky (Child's Play 4) (1998)
path_1.feeling: Self-aware slasher camp that’s more goofy than gripping for me.

path_1.title: Carrie (1976)
path_1.feeling: Elegant, tragic, and genuinely unsettling—classic done right.

path_1.title: Nightbreed (1990)
path_1.feeling: Imaginative monsters and world-building, but messy storytelling keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2, The (1986)
path_1.feeling: Gonzo splatter satire that entertains in bursts but isn’t my jam.

path_1.title: Crimson Peak (2015)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous gothic romance with enough ghosts and mood to keep me invested.

path_1.title: V/H/S (2012)
path_1.feeling: Uneven anthology with a couple standout segments and plenty of filler.

path_1.title: Halloween (1978)
path_1.feeling: Lean, suspenseful, and foundational—still creeps under my skin.

path_1.title: Resident Evil (2002)
path_1.feeling: Serviceable action-horror with slick style but little real scares.

path_1.title: Doghouse (2009)
path_1.feeling: Crass zombie-comedy premise wears thin fast despite a few gags.

path_1.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_1.feeling: Samey alien-abduction thrills—some atmosphere, not much originality.

path_1.title: Deadpool (2016)
path_1.feeling: Snarky, kinetic fun that entertains even if the superhero beats feel familiar.

path_1.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_1.feeling: Classic sci‑fi morality tale that’s more interesting than frightening.

path_1.title: Shutter (2004)
path_1.feeling: Creepy imagery and guilt-driven mystery that delivers solid J‑horror chills.

path_2.title: Devil's Rejects, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Grimy, nihilistic road-sadism that numbed me more than it unnerved me.

path_2.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
path_2.feeling: Austere cosmic awe that leaves me hushed and a little haunted.

path_2.title: Vampire Hunter D (1985)
path_2.feeling: Moody gothic splashes and cool lore, but it skims where I want it to sink.

path_2.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_2.feeling: Playful menace and tactile makeup that still conjure a cozy little chill.

path_2.title: Housebound (2014)
path_2.feeling: Spry, twisty haunting with enough atmosphere to keep the laughs from deflating it.

path_2.title: FearDotCom (a.k.a. Fear.com) (a.k.a. Fear Dot Com) (2002)
path_2.feeling: Tech-tinged nastiness with cheap jolts and thin dread.

path_2.title: American Haunting, An (2005)
path_2.feeling: Starchy period chills that feel more rote than ruinous.

path_2.title: Queen of the Damned (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sexy-gloss vampire posturing that left me cold.

path_2.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_2.feeling: Derivative cabin-in-the-woods abduction beats with fleeting unease.

path_2.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_2.feeling: Visceral, propulsive vengeance that grips even as it repels.

path_2.title: Signal, The (2014)
path_2.feeling: Intriguing setup that drifts into muddled, clinical chills.

path_2.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic, uncertainty-soaked tension that keeps the nerves taut.

path_2.title: Altered (2006)
path_2.feeling: Small-scale alien payback with grim energy and intermittent shivers.

path_2.title: Pumpkinhead (1988)
path_2.feeling: Backwoods folklore and creature wrath that’s atmospheric if uneven.

path_2.title: Innkeepers, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: A patient, low-key haunting that hums with end-of-shift melancholy.

path_2.title: Bride of Chucky (Child's Play 4) (1998)
path_2.feeling: Self-aware splatter goofs that dilute the dread I’m chasing.

path_2.title: Carrie (1976)
path_2.feeling: High-school cruelty curdled into tragedy with steady, unnerving build.

path_2.title: Nightbreed (1990)
path_2.feeling: Monstrous mythology with a dark fairy-tale pull, more curious than chilling.

path_2.title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2, The (1986)
path_2.feeling: Grotesque, screaming slapstick that bulldozes the atmosphere I crave.

path_2.title: Crimson Peak (2015)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous gothic gloom whose romance and ghosts whisper more than they bite.

path_2.title: V/H/S (2012)
path_2.feeling: Found-footage grab bag—uneven, but a few segments get under the skin.

path_2.title: Halloween (1978)
path_2.feeling: Clean, relentless shape-in-the-shadows dread that still crawls under the skin.

path_2.title: Resident Evil (2002)
path_2.feeling: Sterile action-horror slickness with sporadic tension but little lingering fear.

path_2.title: Doghouse (2009)
path_2.feeling: Laddish splatter farce that wears out its welcome fast.

path_2.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_2.feeling: Abduction shocks and screaming don’t quite cohere into lasting dread.

path_2.title: Deadpool (2016)
path_2.feeling: Snarky, hyper-violent caper that entertains in bursts but leaves me untouched.

path_2.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_2.feeling: Classic morality-tale sci-fi with a cool chill and sturdy, slow dread.

path_2.title: Shutter (2004)
path_2.feeling: A cool, creeping curse that builds a pleasingly oppressive hush.

path_2.title: Devil's Rejects, The (2005)
path_2.feeling: Grimy, nihilistic cruelty that smothers the slow-burn dread I seek.

path_2.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
path_2.feeling: Austere, cosmic awe that sinks in like a deep-space prayer.

path_2.title: Vampire Hunter D (1985)
path_2.feeling: Moody gothic sci‑fi vibes I enjoy, even if the pulp keeps me at a distance.

path_2.title: Witches, The (1990)

path_2.title: Housebound (2014)
path_2.feeling: Light on real chills but the craft and timing keep a pleasant shiver going.

path_2.title: Old Boy (2003)

path_2.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)

path_2.feeling: Winky splatter antics that undercut any real fear.

path_3.title: Devil's Rejects, The (2005)
path_3.feeling: Mean-spirited road nightmare with little of the atmosphere I crave, though a few tense chases land.

path_3.title: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968)
path_3.feeling: Transcendent, hypnotic sci‑fi that stirs awe and unease in equal measure.

path_3.title: Vampire Hunter D (1985)
path_3.feeling: Gothic futurism and cool mood pieces I like, but it never fully chills me.

path_3.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_3.feeling: Darkly playful fantasy whose macabre wit and child-in-peril stakes keep me engaged.

path_3.title: Housebound (2014)
path_3.feeling: Clever, cozy haunt with enough genuine creep and character to keep me smiling and tense.

path_3.title: FearDotCom (a.k.a. Fear.com) (a.k.a. Fear Dot Com) (2002)
path_3.feeling: A noisy tech-curse premise with scant atmosphere or lingering dread.

path_3.title: American Haunting, An (2005)
path_3.feeling: Period ghostliness I usually love, but this felt rote and rarely unsettling.

path_3.title: Queen of the Damned (2002)
path_3.feeling: Stylized vampire theatrics that smother any real menace or mood.

path_3.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_3.feeling: Alien-in-the-woods chaos with flashes of tension but little sustained unease.

path_3.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_3.feeling: A bleak, propulsive revenge mystery that grips even as its extremity keeps me at arm’s length.

path_3.title: Signal, The (2014)
path_3.feeling: An eerie waking-nightmare setup that intrigues more than it ultimately satisfies.

path_3.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_3.feeling: Tense, claustrophobic survival mind games that kept me guessing.

path_3.title: Altered (2006)
path_3.feeling: Small-scale alien payback with a grim edge that works in moments, not as a whole.

path_3.title: Pumpkinhead (1988)
path_3.feeling: Backwoods witchcraft and a mournful monster give this a satisfying folk-horror weight.

path_3.title: Innkeepers, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: A gentle slow-burn haunt whose cozy melancholy and late jolts suit my taste.

path_3.title: Bride of Chucky (Child's Play 4) (1998)
path_3.feeling: Self-aware slashes and gags that amuse more than they unnerve.

path_3.title: Carrie (1976)
path_3.feeling: A cruel coming-of-age nightmare whose slow, tragic swell still chills.

path_3.title: Nightbreed (1990)
path_3.feeling: Imaginative hidden-monster world I admire, though it’s more fantasy than fear for me.

path_3.title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2, The (1986)
path_3.feeling: Loud, manic mayhem where the humor drowns out the dread I seek.

path_3.title: Crimson Peak (2015)
path_3.feeling: Sumptuous gothic romance and whispering ghosts—mood-rich, if emotionally muted for me.

path_3.title: V/H/S (2012)
path_3.feeling: Jittery found-footage fragments with a few strong chills amid the noise.

path_3.title: Halloween (1978)
path_3.feeling: Lean, methodical stalking that distills dread to its essentials.

path_3.title: Resident Evil (2002)
path_3.feeling: Slick, corridor-bound carnage with minimal atmosphere and stakes.

path_3.title: Doghouse (2009)
path_3.feeling: Broad, jokey premise that undercuts tension and leaves little lingering unease.

path_3.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_3.feeling: Serviceable alien panic without the lingering, quiet dread I latch onto.

path_3.title: Deadpool (2016)
path_3.feeling: Snappy, irreverent action that entertains even if I miss the moody chill.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: A neat sci‑fi morality tale that intrigues more than it unnerves.

path_3.title: Shutter (2004)

path_3.title: Doghouse (2009)

path_3.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)

path_3.title: Shutter (2004)

path_3.title: Devil's Rejects, The (2005)

path_3.title: Housebound (2014)
path_3.feeling: Clever, cozy haunt with spry wit

path_3.title: FearDotCom (a.k.a. Fear.com) (a.k.a. Fear Dot Com) (2002)
path_3.feeling: Early-2000s techno-gloom heavy on noise and jump scares, light on convincing dread.

path_3.title: American Haunting, An (2005)
path_3.feeling: Period spookery with some atmosphere, but thin, repetitive frights that never really bite.

path_3.title: Queen of the Damned (2002)
path_3.feeling: Glossy vamp rock-opera sheen smothers the menace and leaves me unmoved.

path_3.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_3.feeling: Loud, derivative cabin-in-the-woods alien mayhem with little lingering unease.

path_3.title: Old Boy (2003)
path_3.feeling: Operatic, grim revenge puzzle that absorbs and unsettles more than it outright scares.

path_3.title: Signal, The (2014)
path_3.feeling: Sleek, disorienting sci-fi mystery whose cool mood intrigues more than it satisfies.

path_3.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
path_3.feeling: Tense, sealed-room paranoia that hums nicely even if the landing wobbles.

path_3.title: Altered (2006)
path_3.feeling: Gritty, small-scale alien payback with a decent sour mood but limited afterglow.

path_3.title: Pumpkinhead (1988)
path_3.feeling: Rural gothic revenge with a great creature and misty mood, a touch too straightforward.

path_3.title: Innkeepers, The (2011)
path_3.feeling: Gentle, patient haunt whose soft build delivers hushed, satisfying chills.

path_3.title: Bride of Chucky (Child's Play 4) (1998)
path_3.feeling: Campy, self-aware splatter that amuses more than it unnerves.

path_3.title: Carrie (1976)
path_3.feeling: Dreamy, cruel coming-of-age horror whose slow, stylish burn hits my wavelength.

path_3.title: Nightbreed (1990)
path_3.feeling: Imaginative dark fantasy that is too rambunctious to sustain real dread.

path_3.title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2, The (1986)
path_3.feeling: Grotty, gleeful carnage pitched to cartoon

path_3.title: Crimson Peak (2015)
path_3.feeling: Lush gothic romance where the sumptuous design outshines the actual haunt.

path_3.title: V/H/S (2012)
path_3.feeling: Anthology jitters with occasional inspired nastiness, but the found-footage chaos is uneven.

path_3.title: Halloween (1978)
path_3.feeling: Elegant, minimalist stalking that lets silence and shape do the creeping I love.

path_3.title: Resident Evil (2002)
path_3.feeling: Slick, gamey action-horror that trades dread for gunfire and monsters.

path_3.title: Doghouse (2009)
path_3.feeling: Laddish, jokey gore whose tone smothers any real tension.

path_3.title: Extraterrestrial (2014)
path_3.feeling: Noisy abduction thrills and thin characters leave little to linger.

path_3.title: Deadpool (2016)
path_3.feeling: Snarky, hyperactive superhero romp that is breezy fun but not my flavor of thrill.

path_3.title: Fly, The (1958)
path_3.feeling: Classic sci-fi melodrama with a neat premise, more curiosity than creeping dread for me.

path_3.title: Shutter (2004)
path_3.feeling: Moody, guilt-soaked ghost story whose quiet images linger like a bruise.

path_3.feeling: Grimy, mean-spirited road horror with stray atmosphere but too much cruelty for me
